Name: Thomas Jenkins

Address: Pantcefn Farm, Llanarth, Cardiganshire

Occupation, profession or business: Farmer

Attested or not attested: Attested

Grounds: (a) That the farm of Pantcefn of which the Appellant is tenant contains 93 acres of arable and pasture land. (b) That the said farm requires two teams of horses for its proper cultivation. (c) That the Appellant's two sons Rees Jenkins aged 30 and the said Thomas Jenkins aged 26 are both employed to follow the said teams. (d) That the said Thomas Jenkins is equally indispensible as a workman on the said farm with the said Rees Jenkins who has been exempted from Military Service. (e) That the Appellant is 60 years old and for physical reasons is unable to do any manual labour on the said farm. (f) That wihout the services of the said Thomas Jenkins the said farm cannot be carried on.

Signature of appellant: Griffith Jenkins

Address of appellant: Pantcefn Farm, Llanarth

Occupation, profession or business: Farmer

Why appellant acts for the man: As his employer

Description: Notice of Claim by Employer

Transcription: NOTICE OF CLAIM BY EMPLOYER TO BE FILLED UP BY EMPLOYER (A duplicate must be filled up, in the official form provided, and forwarded at the same time.) 1. Employer - Name Griffith Jenkins Address Pantcefn Llanarth Cardshire Business Farmer 2. Attested Man - Name Thomas Jenkins Address Pantcefn, Llanarth Cardshire Occupation Farm Hand Where attested Lampeter Number of Group age 26. Group 9. 3. To what group postponement is requested. 4. Whether the man is willing to remain in the employer's sevice if the claim is allowed. (The form must contain a definite statement that he is willing. He may signify his willingness by a signed statement in this space or personally to the Committee when the case is heard. If one or other of these is not done, the claim cannot be entertained.) I am willing to remain in my employers service if this claim is allowed. Signed: Thomas Jenkins. 5. Grounds on which the application is made. (The grounds must be clearly stated. It should be shown (a) not only that the man is individually indispensable, but also (b) that every effort has been made to find a temporary substitute; (c) that it is in the national interest that the employer's business should be maintained because it ministers to war requirements, to essential domestic needs or to the export trade; (d) the employer must also show that he has given reasonable facilities to other employees, if any, to enlist.) - 1. My farm Pantcefn is 93 acres in extent, and is principally very heavy corn land. And the two men that I employ are wholly in charge of my teams of horses, and are therefore absolutely indispensable, and without them the work on this farm cannot be carried on. 2. The casual labourer I used to employ has already joined the Royal Field Artillery, and it is quite impossible to find a substitute in the district. 3. Without the two men employed, I should be compelled to discontine producing food essential to the community. 4. I am now 59 yrs of age and physically unable to do any work myself. I have 5 draught working horses and other young horses. Signed - Griffith Jenkins, Feb 9th 1916

Name: Rees James Davies

Age: 19 Years

Address: Moelfryn Mawr, Bethania, Llanon

Occupation, profession or business: Cowman and shepherd, the responsiblility of these animals lies entirely upon him throuhout the year, also some labour work if time permits.

Tag: Beige R41/42: Page 1

Reasons: Application is made on the grounds that my son Rees James Davies is indispensable to me on my farm of 168 acres. He has 30 cattle depended upon him. Also chaffing & pulping must be done by him. He has also 80 sheep to look after which requires great care at lambing as farm is situated on high elevation and open. If time affords he will have to do some Harrowing while his brother is sowing and as farm is situated on hilly ground, it requires more labour in order to secure safety. for example We must have 3 horses atached [sic] to the cart before we can take the farmyard manure away from the yard. Therefore he must help his brother before this work can be done. And as labourers are unobtainable, he has to do all the labour work that must be done, for example, cutting turf, in order to secure fire through the winter, thatching all the corn and hay. Therefore the services of my son is urgently needed & his work must be done in order to secure food for the nation in her hour of her greatest need and if I was to lose the services of my son, I should have to give up farming.

Signature: John Davies

Address: Moelfryn Mawr

Decision of the Tribunal: Application refused E. James Price 8th. March 1916

Grounds: I am a widow 63 years of age. I hold a farm of 330 acres of which 75 to 80 acres is arable every year. I sell large quantity of wheat and other corn every year. I keep 17 - 20 horses. 50 cattle. 80 ewe sheep. 30 pigs. 3 breeding sows. My son Alun J Jones in respect of whom I make this appeal has just had his 19. He is one out of three working on the farm. Another English boy of 18 who was in my service, left me a month ago. I offered him £15 for staying, but he had determined to go and work in the ammunition works. I wrote several letters to Industrial schools and elsewhere in search of another one, but hitherto failed to get one. I have only one daughter and a girl of 13 working as females. The said Alun J Jones appealed for exemption under the military service act, but was rejected by the local Tribunal on the grounds that I got another son in college at Bala Bangor. I beg to state as regards this boy Simon Jones that he is absolutely unfit for any kind of manual labour, to which a medical certificate will be produced. He was warned by doctors to abandon any kind of work. He met with an accident 4 years ago in a ship by falling in to the hold. He had a compound fracture in one thigh, a fracture in the other knee, got his eye affected through it, was lain up for 4 months in hospital in Buenos Ayres. He has to keep one heel in pad and is under medicine ever since. If I am not allowed to keep three men on this large farm, there is no hesitation I'll have to give the farm up and quit. My other son Evan G Jones 24 was only allowed temporary exemption which is to me inexplicable.

Signature of appellant: Mary Jones

Address of appellant: Cilie Farm Cross Inn SO. Cards

Occupation, profession or business: Farmer

Name: William Evan Baker

Age: 25

Address: Brynbeddau, Bethania Llanon Cards

Occupation, profession or business: Farmer - all general farm work. Ploughing. sowing. harvesting. etc.

Grounds: A G.

Nature of application: Application made for absolute exemption, on the ground that my personal labour and superintendence is indispensable for the proper cultivation of my holding. Written below App. refused

Tag: Beige R41/42: Page 1

Reasons: Our farm being a small place, 22 acres in extent, 15 acres being arable land & the rest pasture and I am the only male person on the place. My aunt. Magdalen Jones, the occupier 60 years of age being a reumatic cripple, is at times totally incapable of any work. She is therefore wholly dependent on me for all the work that's to be done on the place and consequently if I was to go away she would be placed in a very difficult position. The cultivation of the holding as it is, does not yield enough profit so as to pay for hired labour, which would be impossible to get in our neighbourhood. Therefore the only possible solution would be to sell out and vacate the place, which would mean our ruin. Also about two years ago , in order to cultvate our farm to a better advantage I took on the responsibility of ploughing and sowing a neighbours farm, and in return I get the loan of their pair of horses to do all the necessary work on our place, and now owing to the scarcity of labourers in the district, I am the only male person in both places. In consequence of my aunts infirmity, all the work of feeding our cattle, milking atc. at times falls on me, in addition to general outdoor work, ploughing, sowing, harvesting etc. If hard work on a farm is expedient to the national interest, I honestly believe I ought to secure an absolute exemption. My case being rather complicated I have explained to the best of my ability, but any other possible information will be readily submitted, and any inquiry to the circumstances will be openly admitted.

Signature: William E Baker

Address: Brynbeddau, Bethania, Llanon, Cards.

Occupation, profession or business: Farmer

Why application made by applicant for the man: Man

Transcription: Brynonnen, LLANARTH, Cardiganshire 17th July 1916 Messrs James Rees, Wm Rees and Evan Jones, Masons, signed a contract for the Masons work and Mr. J.W.Evans signed a contract for the carpenters work, - to build a house at Cei Bach, Llanarth, Cardiganshire for Mrs Ward of Ridgmead, The Ridgeway, Enfield, Middlesex. They stipulated that if they could get another Mason and that if neither of them would be ill, that they would complete the house by the first week in August. It seemed then, that the work could be completed by the first week in August. If Mr J.W.Evans cannot be allowed to complete his part of the work it will be most difficult to find another man to replace him and finish the building. Richard E, Bevan. Agent for Mrs Ward

Transcription: Brynmarlais Ammanford Augst 25th 1916 Dear Sir I beg to thank you for the notice of appeal for Mr William Jones. It is too far for me to appear therefore I beg to lay the facts before you which please lay before the Tribunal. William Jones was lately employed by me in carting pitwood from Llangeitho to Pontlanio station therefore was in charge of two horses & gambo. He met with an accident about a month ago and broke his arm but I hope he will soon return to his work at any rate as soon as he is well again During his absence I have been able to get temporary assistance from a small farmer in the neighbourhood who has now to return to his farm to harvest his corn. It is impossible to get a man up there to take charge of the horses, and I fear I will have to leave these in the stable, unless William Jones returns to his work I have a contract with the Ammanford Colliery to supply them with pitwood so I must leave the matter to the Tribunal Yours faithfully H Herbert.

Transcription: William Evans, Glynrodyn Farm, is a retired Master Mariner, 78 years of age, who followed his occupation on sea up to 10 years ago. He farms Glynrodyn, a holding of 67 acres, which was rented before he purchased it for £56. 28 acres is being ploughed and 10 acres under hay. All the farm is cultivated in rotation, with the exception of 5 acres, of steep dingle. The soil mostly is heavy and wet, and laborious to work, consequently tillage is in a very backward state, owing to the lateness and severity of the season. The stock consists of 4 working horses and a colt, two teams being engaged for spring work, 7 milking cows and 15 other cattle and 6 pigs. All hands on the farm are the said William Evans aged 78 years and his wife 76, a son of 43, and the appellant a lad of 18, classified B1 by the Medical Board. Also tramp labour used to be employed when available, but nowadays it is impossible to get this, therefore it is essential that this lad should be retained in order to carry on the farm work at its highest efficiency.

Description: Statement from JENKIN GARFIELD THOMAS Blaenclettwr Talgarreg in support of Thomas Thomas

Transcription: No. 14 in List. JENKIN GARFIELD THOMAS of Blaenclettwr, Talgarreg saith:- I am 32 years old and am tenant of Blaenclettwr Farm containing 375 acres at £85 rent. My farm is an upland holding in the Parish of Llanarth and is peculiarly situated from the fact that the farmhouse and buildings are quite a mile from any District roads and are approached from such roads along very rough tracks through fields. The rent is low because of the situation of the farm. I became a tenant of the farm at Michaelmas 1915 when it was arranged between me and my brother Thomas Thomas(the man in this case) that in consequence of my ill health he should remain in my service for a number of years until I had established myself. I have never been in good health and I am continually suffering from bronchitis and asthma which confine me to bed from time to time - My last attack recently laying me up for 3 weeks in bed. I annex Medical certificate. My staff consists of :- Myself, Thomas Thomas, John Davies(a lad of 16 years last birthday), My Wife 27, Hannah Jones aged 22, Mary Evans aged 15. My stock consists of :- HORSES :- 6 working 3 teams 4 other CATTLE:- 16 Milch cows 15 store 10 calves 100 ewes Pigs etc I have had ploughed 60 acres of land which is not seeded being 12 to 13 acres more than was under plough last year, but I have not ploughed any of this myself. I have 25 acres under hay. The boundary of my farm extends to about 3 miles and it is fenced with barbed wire and the repair and maintenance of the fence requires much care attention and labour. Thomas Thomas does all the reaping by machine, the thrashing by machine, hay-cutting by machine and I entrust the whole management to him as farm-bailiff - Thomas Thomas is therefore absolutely indispensable to me for carrying on the farm and a substitute could not fill his place. Thomas Thomas also sells and buys at fairs and markets for me when I am prevented from doing so by illness. Unless I am permitted to retain Thomas Thomas' services I shall be obliged to realise my stock etc and give up my farm.

Name of Tribunal: Aberaeron Rural District

Description: Letter from J Garfield Thomas

Transcription: Myself I've some 100 ewes to lamb which will take most of my time on such a big open place. I've got about 3 miles of boundary + much more inside to fence from here till April. Another thing I want to state is, that I reckon my place which is 375 acres, is one of the worst places situated in Cardiganshire as regards roads. I reckon that if any farmer in the Union deserves to keep his man that I am one of them. Description: Typewritten statement headed "No. 16 in list" from David Evans of Alltwen, Ciliau Aeron.

Transcription: No. 16 in List. DAVID EVANS of Alltwen, Ciliau Aeron Tailor saith:- I have been examined by the Medical Board and classed C. 1. I am 29 years old and married. I commenced business on my own account 8 years ago at Alltwen Ciliau Aeron. I have no workmen in my employ, but I have advertised for workmen and for apprentices but without avail. I am therefore fully occupied at my trade. I annex a list of my customers numbering 111, which shows I have a good business connection. My business is partly a credit one and I have debts of various amounts owing to me from customers. I have been granted a Certificate of Exemption twice by Aberayron (Rural) Local Tribunal the Members of which are well acquainted with the circumstances of my case. Being a country tailor my customers would have to go far from their homes to find other tailors if I were called up for service. Transcription: Pantsod, Cross Inn, Cars The Chairman of the Tribunal Sir, In support of my application as to exemption in respect of my son, I beg to submit the following statement to be considered by Tribunal. My farm comprises about 178 acres, of which I have about 56 under plough this year, and about 28 under hay. Out of 10 horses, I have four brood mares in foal, that will leave me by the beginning of May with all my working horses under 3 years old, requiring a very competent man to manage them. Of other sotck, I have 13 Milch cows, 17 yearlings, 8 calves, 50 sheep, 62 lambs, and 14 pigs. I have been for years subject to severe attacks of lumbago, which renders me at times unable to move about without the aid of a stick or two. My wife too, has been subject to rheumatism for years, and is almost unable to move about. Of my 3 daughters, one is a dress maker, and knows but very little of farm work. The other two are in charge of all the house-hold activities, diary work, etc. Of my 3 sons, one is only a boy of 12, with only one arm, The other, although he is 17 years of age, is very slight and weak, and can not be trusted with a pair of young horses. It seems quite obvious therefore that it will be impossible for me to carry on the work of my farm, if my son David, being the only strong and competant man on the farm, is taken away. No substitute will ever do his work, as he is putting in very long hours every day. I am, Sir, respectfully yours, W.Evans April 14th 1917.

Transcription: The Chairman of the Cardiganshire Appeal Tribunal. Sir: In dealing with my case, will you kindly place the following statement before the Tribunal. I am carrying on an extensive business in Drapery, Grocery, Ironmongery, Footware, Earthenware, Manure, and Heavy sack trade, which I have to cart from Aberayron & Llandyssul, distance of about 61/2, & 11, miles respectively. I am doing almost all the carting myself, and delivering the greater part of the goods to customers over a very wide area. I may also state that I do much business on the credit system, and that a large sum of money is now due to me. My wife, owing to continual ill health, is often unable to assist in the shop, so that if I am compelled to join the Army, I will have to do away with my business entirely, I will be unable to meet my creditors, and be landed in financial ruin. Transcription: To, The Chairman and Members of the Cardigan-shire County Appeal Tribunal..... re David M. Morris, Emporium, Llanon. Gentlemen, My son, David M. Morris, is 20 years of age and has been medically examined and placed in Class "A". I (his father) am over 70 years of age and carry on business in Llanon as a draper. I am unable to mange this business owing to being a sufferer from Bronchial Catarrh and the after results of Pneumonia. It is now entirely carried on by my son David, and if he must join the Service the business must be closed. Out of four sons three have joined the Army and are now serving in France and Salonika. So I earnestly appeal to be allowed to retain the services of my fourth boy to keep the business open. If I and my wife could live without depending on the business I would willingly allow my fourth son to fight for his King and Country. Yours truly, Daniel Morris.

Transcription: 6 - The Applicant Evan Glyn Davies manages a Corn and Grist mill in the Village of Aberarth and I Evan Thomas Davies am the owner of same. The Customers for whom I grind number at present 180 and are mostly Farmers and my mill grinds all their wheat and meals for human consumption and other cereals for human consumption and for stock. This mill supplies an area of 7 parishes namely:- Llanddewi Aberarth upper, Henfynyw upper, Llanbadarn, Cilcennin, Llansantffraed, Henfynyw Lower and Llanddewi Aberarth Lower with a population of 4118. If Evan Glyn Davies is taken from me it will be impossible for me to keep the mill open as there is no one available for running it and it requires considerable technical knowledge. The mill works on an average all the year round about 15 hours a day. Within the last two years five other grist mills within a radius of 6 miles from my mill have ceased working and the whole of their trade has been diverted to my mill. The stoppage of this mill would mean a very serious inconvenience to all farmers.
